definition: Wu Zixu (-484 BC), powerful politician in Wu/famous as destitute refugee begging in Wu town, cf 吳市吹簫|吴市吹箫
surname Wu
squad of five soldiers/to associate with/five (banker's anti-fraud numeral)
(noun suffix)

son/child/seed/egg/small thing/1st earthly branch: 11 p.m.-1 a.m., midnight, 11th solar month (7th December to 5th January), year of the Rat/Viscount, fourth of five orders of nobility 五等爵位[wu3 deng3 jue2 wei4]/ancient Chinese compass point: 0° (north)
surname Xu
all/assist/to store

sentences.english: Country full of open-minded hatred of hate at home, Wu may not want to sit still.
sentences.chinese: 国恨家仇满襟怀，伍子胥可不愿坐以待毙。

sentences.english: Yet he suffered agonies of remorse, because his countrymen called him a traitor.
sentences.chinese: 伍子胥虽然报了仇，但是受到国人的责备。

definition: King Gou Jian of Yue (c. 470 BC), sometimes considered one of the Five Hegemons 春秋五霸
King Helu of Wu (-496 BC, reigned 514-496 BC), sometimes considered one of the Five Hegemons 春秋五霸/also called 吳王闔廬|吴王阖庐
King Helu of Wu (-496 BC, reigned 514-496 BC)/also called 闔廬|阖庐
Fan Li (536-488 BC), politician of Yue state, businessman and economist
King Gou Jian of Yue (c. 470 BC), sometimes considered one of the Five Hegemons 春秋五霸
Wu state (in south China, in different historical periods)/Wu state 220-280, founded by Sun Quan 孫權|孙权 the southernmost of the three Kingdoms
King Zhuang of Chu (reigned 613-591 BC), one of the Five Hegemons 春秋五霸
Duke Wen of Jin (697-628 BC, reigned 636-628 BC), one of the Five Hegemons 春秋五霸
King Huai of Chu (reigned 328-299 BC)/later King Huai of Chu (reigned 208-205 BC)
the state of Chu, one of the most important of the small states contending for power in China between 770 and 223 BC, located around present-day Hubei
Wu She (-522 BC), powerful minister of Chu and father of Wu Zixu 伍子胥
Duke Huan of Qi (reigned 685-643 BC), one of the Five Hegemons 春秋五霸
Wen Zhong (-467 BC), adviser to the state of Yue during Spring and Autumn period
Zhang Yi (-309 BC), political strategist of the School of Diplomacy 縱橫家|纵横家[Zong4 heng2 jia1] during the Warring States Period (475-221 BC)

Shang Yang (c. 390-338 BC), legalist philosopher and statesman of the state of Qin 秦國|秦国[Qin2 guo2], whose reforms paved the way for the eventual unification of the Chinese empire by the Qin dynasty 秦朝|秦朝[Qin2 chao2]
Guan Zhong (-645 BC), famous politician of Qi 齊國|齐国 of Spring and Autumn period/known as Guangzi 管子
